displaytitle: Gabbra Matriarch with Gabbra Women and Children, Ethiopian Refugee Camp, Walda, Kenya
creditline: Museum purchase, gift of John B. Elliot, Class of 1951
inscribed:
a: Numbered in ink, verso upper right corner: 1 [encircled]
Signed in graphite, verso lower right corner: Fazal Sheikh 1 of 3

b: Numbered in ink, verso lower left corner: 2
Inscribed and signed in graphite, verso lower edge: Gabbra Matriarch with Gabbra women and children, Ethiopian refugee camp, Walda, Kenya, 1993 / Fazal Sheikh March 1994. Printed for the Art Museum Princeton University 2 of 3

c: Numbered in ink, verso lower left corner: 3
Signed in graphite, verso lower right corner: Fazal Sheikh 3 of 3

Note: prints have been trimmed and mounted; inscriptions now concealed.

In ink on mount, below center print: Gabbra matriarch with women and children, Ethiopian refugee camp, Walda, Kenya 1993 / © Fazal Sheikh

titles.title: Gabbra Matriarch with Gabbra Women and Children, Ethiopian Refugee Camp, Walda, Kenya

makers.displaydate: born 1965, New York, NY; active New York, NY and Zurich, Switzerland
makers.displaymaker: Fazal Sheikh, born 1965, New York, NY; active New York, NY and Zurich, Switzerland

texts.textentryhtml: Fazal Sheikh, an American with family ties to Pakistan and Kenya, is known for his haunting images of displaced persons. This triptych, an assemblage of three images, shows women and children from Ethiopia in a refugee camp in Kenya. A beautiful group portrait of people in a tragic predicament, it asks viewers to consider uncomfortable questions: what is the relationship  between the photographer and his subjects? How does the subjects’ suffering relate to the artist’s aesthetic and political concerns?

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1994," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 54, no. 1 (1995): p. 40-79.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1994," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 54, no. 1 (1995): p. 40-79., p. 65

bibliography.boilertext: A Sense of Common Ground: Photographs from Kenya's Northern Frontier (Syracuse: Robert B. Menschel Gallery 34, 1993).
bibliography.citation: A Sense of Common Ground: Photographs from Kenya's Northern Frontier (Syracuse: Robert B. Menschel Gallery 34, 1993).
